title: Despite reports of a shortfall of $1.8 billion, Alberta Darling says Wisconsin has a surplus of $443 million.
text: On September 8, 2014, the report of the Legislative Tax Office in Wisconsin published the headlines of news that the State budget faces an estimated US$ 1.8 billion "deficit." On the same day, Ms. Alberta Darling, a Republic of Milwaukee suburbs, announced what seemed to be a contradictory statement. "Wisconsin has no disability," said Darling in a newsletter, released with GOP Republic. "Thank you for the Republic's reforms, the 2014 budget will start with a surplus of $443 million." :: Al-Aziz and Nigren are co-chairs of the Joint Finance Committee of the Legislature, which plays a key role in the formulation of the Government ' s signed budget into law. (Scott Walker) So taxpayers in Wisconsin (and voters in the next election to the office of Governor) would like to know: does the state government have a deficit, a surplus, or what? The basic budget of Wisconsin is, of course, a two-year document. Therefore, there is no "budget for 2014," as Darling said. However, more than two months after the fiscal year from 1 July 2014 to 30 June 2015. This is the second half of the 2013-15 budget. These time points are important because the law stipulates that the State budget for the biennium must be balanced. An actual deficit cannot be activated. What has attracted the headlines is the Office's expectation that "the State's obligation over the year" - often referred to as the deficit or deficit "structural" - is $1.8 billion for the next budget period, 2015-17. This is an estimate of the amount of the budget for the next biennium -- if there are no changes in income or expenditure -- it will be unbalanced. In other words, the shortage is not real red ink. This is now Darling ' s claim. Surplus? The Darling Office referred to the Legislative Tax Office's memorandum issued five days before the $1.8 billion memorandum. The Office is a non-partisan agency that the political parties consider to be the gold standard in budgetary matters. The previous note indicates that 2014-15, the second year of the current biennial budget, began on 1 July 2014 with a balance of $443 million. So, it's true that at this moment in time -- the midpoint of the two-year budget -- books in black. However, the same note also presents the budget picture for the second year of the session. That is, it shows what money is expected to come from, and how much it is expected to come out of. It shows that the surplus of $443 million was swallowed and that the State faces a "income shortfall" of about $116 million - since its revision to $396 million - by the end of the fiscal year - 30 June 2015. That's because the collection of taxes was less than expected. As we have stated, the State cannot suffer from an actual deficit. Accordingly, the Finance Office stated that the State may need an invoice for budget reform by 30 June 2015 unless revenue is higher than currently anticipated and/or if expenditure is not reduced. Depending on the size of the revenue deficit, it is also possible for Walker's administration to reduce spending - by not filling open positions, for example - enough to eliminate the need for a budget reform bill. Therefore, as of now, the State budget has a surplus of $443 million, but this is expected to become a deficit of $396 million by next June.
